Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: GOALI: Bridging the Theory-Practice Divide in Multimedia Compression

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Data compression is a central problem in engineering, both in a practical and conceptual sense. On the practical side, modern telecommunications would be impossible without sophisticated data compression algorithms, and improved compression schemes will lead to improved connectivity. On the conceptual side, since compressing a source amounts to learning its structure, data compression serves as a concrete problem with a well-defined objective that is connected to profound questions in AI. For compression of multimedia sources in particular, there has been relatively little interplay between the theoretical and experimental communities. This is arguably attributable to a lack of realism in the mathematical models used in theoretical studies and by a marked disconnection between the two communities. The GOALI project will develop new models of multimedia sources, the characterization and analysis of which will likely give rise to new theory.

This project seeks to address both the mathematical realism in multimedia data models and the experimental validation of actual compression algorithms. The technical goal of the project is to develop improved mathematical models for multimedia sources by drawing on recent advances on the experimental side of the field, namely compression via deep neural networks (DNNs). This will be achieved via a collaborative project drawing together two PIs with expertise spanning theoretical and experimental approaches, helping to draw these two sides together. The project will also lead to new characterizations of the expressive power of neural networks for simulating random processes and new results connecting the problems of compression and generative modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data compression enables the modern interconnected world.  Modern telecommunications, from video streaming to ubiquiteous cellular telephony, would be impossible without sophisticated compression technologies, this has been especially true since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. And advances in augmented-reality/virtual-reality (AR/VR) communications will be impossible without advances in data compression.  Data compression is also an important pursuit on purely scientific grounds, due to its deep connections to machine learning and artificial intelligence.

Despite their common technological goal, the theoretical and experimental sides of multimedia data compression have operated separately to a large extent. This is arguably due to (1) a mismatch between the mathematical source models used in theoretical studies and real-world multimedia sources and (2) insufficient interplay between researchers on the theoretical and experimental sides of the field.

This project addressed both factors by supporting a novel collaboration across the theory-experiment divide focused on developing improved source models. The technical approach was to derive new source models by identifying sources that artificial neural networks are particularly adept at compressing. 

The project identified both a suite new source models that help to explain the effectiveness of neural network compressors and the ways in which neural network compressors can be improved. The former potentially sheds some light on the statistical structure of images and other multimedia sources. The latter potentially sheds some light on how to build better compression algorithms that allow for richer communication without requiring additional banwidth. Together, the new models point the way toward to a modern approach to the theory of data compression that better reflects the structure of real-world sources and informs, and is informed by, experimental advances.

The project also identified ways that ideas from the field of data compression can be used to develop new algorithms for core tasks in machine learning.
